Award.AwardTitle: SaTC-EDU: EAGER: Broadening Cyber Security Education Beyond Computing - Educating Everyone to Safeguard Our Online Lives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The growing sophistication of online threats requires that the larger educated workforce understands risks posed by such threats. In recent past, the importance of infusing cyber security concepts in computer science courses has been recognized. This project will explore the viability of an approach that advocates infusion of important cyber security concepts in meaningful context in courses that are part of the general education of undergraduate students across multiple disciplines. Based on a learning sciences informed approach, the project will identify existing courses that provide suitable context for cyber security topics. These courses will range from introductory computing courses to discipline-specific courses in business and public policy colleges at the Georgia Institute of Technology. The relevance of key cyber security concepts in the professional context of various majors will be the primary consideration in identifying courses where these concepts can be infused.

The interdisciplinary project team, with considerable expertise in the learning sciences, will work together to achieve this goal. After a rigorous evaluation and refinements, content modules and experiences will be shared with the larger community for dissemination. By developing an effective approach to infuse key cyber security concepts in courses that are part of the general education of all undergraduates, the project hopes to have impact on the education of the workforce of the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As information technology becomes pervasive, safeguarding our online actions becomes critical. The goal of this project was to explore novel ways to integrate basic cybersecurity knowledge in appropriate courses so that all undergraduate students are exposed to cybersecurity independent of their majors. For this approach to be effective, it is necessary that this be done in the context of topics that are already included in courses that are part of the educational experience of most undergraduates. This was validated by our research that included engagement with over a dozen instructors who teach courses that provide opportunities for integrating cybersecurity topics. Although many instructors supported the idea of exposing students to cybersecurity topics, they also indicated that it is not feasible to free up time that could be explicitly devoted to a new cybersecurity module. Because of this, the project focused on identifying existing course topics that could be augmented with cybersecurity concepts.

The project was successful in identifying multiple courses in areas that include computing, public policy and business where cybersecurity concepts can be seamlessly integrated. Content that allows easy adoption by instructors was developed. It is expected that the project will help inform hundreds of undergraduate students about cybersecurity risks and basic cybersecurity hygiene each year.
